contextId.information: "there was a particular" or "there was a." This is a way of introducing a new character in a story. Consider how your language does this. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
This introduces Mary as a new character in the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
Mary traveled with Joseph from Nazareth. It is likely that women were also taxed, so Mary would have needed to travel and be registered as well. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
The word "behold" alerts us to a new person in the story. Your language may have a way of doing this. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
This introduces a new participant into the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
contextId.quote: A prophetess named Anna was there

contextId.information: This phrase is used to mark the introduction of a new character into the story; in this case, a demon-possessed man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
These are new people in the story. Your language may have a way of showing that these are new people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
Jesus now begins to speak to the entire crowd, rather than just to his disciples. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])

The word "behold" alerts us to the introduction of the dead man into the story. Your language may have a way of doing this. AT: "there was a dead man who" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
contextId.quote: behold, a man who had died

contextId.information: The word "behold" alerts us to a new person in the story. Your language may have a way of doing this. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
This introduces a new character in the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
This expression introduces a new person in the story, but does not identify him by name. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
This introduces a new person in the story without giving his name. We know only that he was from Samaria. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
This introduces Martha as a new character. Your language may have a way of introducing new people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])

The word "behold" alerts us to a new person in the story. Your language may have a way of doing this. English uses "There in front of him was a man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
contextId.quote: Behold, there in front of him was a man

contextId.information: This introduces a new character in the parable. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
contextId.quote: There was a certain rich man

contextId.information: This phrase introduces a person in Jesus' story. It is not clear if this was a real person, or simply a story that Jesus told in order to make a point. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])

This phrase introduces another person in Jesus' story. It is not clear if this was a real person, or simply a story that Jesus told in order to make a point. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
Jesus uses this phrase to introduce a new character to the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
This introduces a new character in the story. It only identifies him by his position. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])

"there was a blind man sitting." Here "certain" means only that the man is an important new participant to the story but Luke does not mention his name. He is a new participant in the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
contextId.quote: a certain blind man was sitting

contextId.information: This is a way of introducing a new character to the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
The word "behold" alerts us to a new group in the story. Your language may have a way of doing this. AT: "there was a crowd that appeared" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
